title: N33 Billion Meant for Weapons Bought Land and Funded Saudi Transfers Instead
content:
this is not a movie. this happened in court today.

an efcc investigator stood in front of a judge and started reading numbers. not small numbers. the kind that make your brain glitch for a second because surely you misheard.

N33 billion. with a B. billion naira that was supposed to buy weapons while boko haram was literally tearing through the northeast.

instead? land in abuja. properties. dollar transfers to saudi arabia.

i wish i was making this up.

the account that went from broke to balling overnight

so michael adarikun, this efcc detective, testified about how N2.2 billion moved from sambo dasuki's office (he was the national security adviser) into a private company called acacia holdings limited.

the company belonged to aminu baba-kusa, some former nnpc guy.

here's the funny part - and by funny i mean absolutely insane:

before the money hit, acacia holdings had N27,000 in their account. twenty-seven thousand naira. you probably have more than that in your savings right now.

then boom. hundreds of millions start flowing in. from "broke student" to "billionaire" overnight.

where did all the money go?

the investigator literally sat there reading out transfers like he was reading a shopping list:

  • N600 million here
  • N650 million there
  • N750 million to some hospital

then it got weirdly specific. like they weren't even trying to hide it anymore.

N70 million to some guy named jubril abdullahi. N50 million straight to baba-kusa himself. N20 million here. N2 million there to a staff member (suraya maigida, in case you're wondering).

N15 million went to ibrahim saleh - apparently the designated property buyer. that specific payment? for something called 'hospitality property nigeria.'

then someone withdrew N250 million with the label 'miscellaneous customer service.' miscellaneous. customer. service.

brother, what kind of customer service costs N250 million?

another N2 million to 'facilitate the retention of a plot of land at wuse 2.' then N25 million more a few days later because why not.

the islamic academy that wasn't about education

N60 million allegedly went to an islamic academy. sounds noble right?

wrong.

it was for land. 3.62 hectares in kyami district opposite centenary city along airport road. not a single naira for education.

survey fees. beacon processing. stadium layouts. all funded with money meant to buy weapons.

let that sink in.

the saudi transfer that lost $370,000 somewhere

this one is wild even by nigerian standards.

N55.9 million moved to facilitate a $1 million foreign transfer to saudi arabia.

guess how much actually made it to saudi? $630,000.

the remaining $370,000? vanished. poof. gone.

nobody knows where. nobody's saying.

some context because this is actually insane

remember 2014-2015? boko haram was destroying the northeast. soldiers were literally begging for equipment on social media. dying because they didn't have proper weapons.

dasuki was the guy in charge of buying those weapons. he had the budget. N33 billion (and that's just what we know about).

buhari's audit panel later found that $2 billion for arms was just... gone. unaccounted for.

this trial started in 2015. it's 2026 now. eleven years. we're still in court listening to testimony about bank transfers from over a decade ago.

early on, the sss literally refused to release dasuki on bail even though courts kept ordering them to. they just... didn't.

the defense is fighting back

when the efcc tried to submit baba-kusa's statement as evidence, his lawyers objected hard.

they claimed it was made under duress in an efcc underground cell. the prosecution said no, it was in a public area with his lawyer present.

so now the judge ordered a trial-within-a-trial just to figure out if the statement counts. the case continues february 24.

the part that keeps me up at night

all of this was said under oath. in open court. sworn testimony.

while boko haram was massacring people, while soldiers were dying with outdated weapons, someone allegedly used N33 billion to buy land in abuja and send money to saudi arabia.

N33 billion could've changed everything. equipped an entire army. maybe saved thousands of lives.

instead, if these allegations are true, it bought properties and facilitated dollar transfers.

the trial continues. eleven years later, we're still counting.
excerpt: an efcc investigator testified in court about how n33 billion meant for weapons ended up funding land purchases, properties, and foreign transfers
